raw_text:
Lewsey puzzle over disallowed try
 
 England's Josh Lewsey has claimed he was denied a late try in his side's Six Nations loss to Ireland.
 
 The Wasps wing insisted he grounded the ball when he was bundled over the line and said referee Jonathan Kaplan had made a wrong decision. "I'm positive I touched the ball down over the line," Lewsey told BBC Sport. "It certainly wasn't a turnover. "I was driven over and I put the ball on the ground. The whistle went and I let go of the ball." Lewsey added: "One of the Irish players scooped it back after the whistle and to our surprise the referee then gave a turnover. "As far as I'm concerned, that incident and Mark Cueto's effort from Charlie Hodgson's cross-field kick that led to what looked like a good try were the two key elements in the game."
 
 Cueto was also puzzled as to why his try had been disallowed by Kaplan. "I don't think I could have been offside for, without a doubt, I was behind the ball," said the Sale player. "The move was a planned technique, it was not off the cuff. We rehearse it time and time again. "I wouldn't say we were robbed, some decisions go with you and some go against you. Today they went against us and that's tough at international level."
llama3.2:1b: Josh Lewsey claims he was denied a late try by referee Jonathan Kaplan in the Six Nations match against Ireland due to a disputed ground ball.
Lewsey says he grounded the ball after being tackled, but the Irish players then scooped it back.
Referee Kaplan disallowed his try and ruled it a turnover.

Sale player Mark Cueto also had his try disallowed after claiming it was not offside and was part of a planned technique.

Mark Cueto of Sale also disputed his try being disallowed, citing offside and planned technique.

Referee Jonathan Kaplan had ruled it a turnover instead.
Wasps wing said Kaplan made a wrong decision and that one of the Irish players scooped up the ball after the whistle.
Sale player Mark Cueto was also puzzled about his try being disallowed, arguing he wasn't offside and rehearsed the move repeatedly.
He felt decisions went against their team at an international level.
opencoder:1.5b:
"Lewsey puzzle over disallowed try in a game involving England's Josh Lewsey"

England's Josh Lewsey was denied a late try in a Six Nations loss to Ireland following his attempt to ground the ball when he was dragged off the pitch and said that ref.
Jonathan Kaplan made an incorrect decision.
He confirmed this through a statement on BBC Sport, stating that it wasn't a turnover.
"I am confidently saying I touched the ball down over the line."
He then added: "One of the Irish players scooped it back after the whistle and surprised the referee to have a turnover."
The player dismissed the incident as a result of two primary elements in the game – the attempt at grounding the ball and the ref'erence decision.

England's Josh Lewsey said he was driven over and put the ball on the ground after the whistle, but later claimed Mark Cueto's effort from Charlie Hodgson's cross-field kick that led to what looked like a good try were the key elements in the game.
The Wasps team insisted Lewsey touched the ball down over the line when he was bundled over the line and said referee Jonathan Kaplan had made a wrong decision.
"I'm positive I touched the ball down over the line," Lewsey told BBC Sport.
Lewsey added: "One of the Irish players scooped it back after the whistle and to our surprise the referee then gave a turnover.
As far as I'm concerned, that incident and Mark Cueto's effort from Charlie Hodgson's cross-field kick that led to what looked like a good try were the two key elements in the game."
Cueto was also puzzled as to why his try had been disallowed by Kaplan.
"I don't think I could have been offside for, without a doubt, I was behind the ball," said the Sale player.
"The move was a planned technique, it was not off the cuff.
We rehearse it time and time again.
"I wouldn't say we were robbed, some decisions go with you and some go against you.
Today they went against us and that's tough at international level."

He claimed he grounded the ball incorrectly, stating it wasn't a turnover but instead gave a turnover when an Irish player picked up the ball after the whistle.
Cueto explained that his try was disallowed because it wasn't offside, and he believed the kick used was part of their planned technique.
Kaplanski's confusion stemmed from thinking it might be against him for not following their usual strategy.

Lewsey asserts he grounded the ball when being tackled and that Irish players retrieved it after the whistle.
Mark Cueto, another England player, also questioned the disallowed try, claiming he was onside and the play was premeditated, not a spontaneous reaction.
